Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Science-Based Networked Tools for Effective Design and Manufacture of Green Buildings and Green-Building Products
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project relates glare in the design of buildings. The construction industry is currently stifled by the problem of glare, given the limited ability of tools to provide immediate and rigorous analysis that could help users understand where, when, why, how much and how to remedy glare in their buildings. This SBIR project will create the first tool that enables users to automatically perform annual, whole-building glare analysis on their projects without having expertise in daylighting, modeling or simulation. This tool makes possible what was inconceivable before; glare analysis will undoubtedly be a part of the everyday design process of all buildings. Building owners and occupants will require glare analysis. Architects will be able to incorporate these studies during schematic design, and still meet schedule and budget constraints. Manufacturers will be able to refine their products to meet the glare specifications of architects. The market for this technology includes architects, sustainability and lighting consultants, and manufacturers of daylighting products, building owners/homeowners and educators. This tool will directly help make better day lit, energy-efficient buildings, and more importantly help reduce visual discomfort for all occupants who have learned to "accept" glare as a part of life.


This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop a novel glare probe to advance the state of the art for glare analysis thousands fold, plus provide actionable information for manufacturers to specify their products on a range of design problems. Through the use of cloud computing, advanced algorithms in conjunction with user-input will be researched to highly streamline robust glare analysis on a building-wide scale. This probe will report back both interactive graphical maps as well as several metrics of performance. Users will be able to flexibly and quickly assign and compare different manufactured products. This technology will be used by manufacturer salespeople to easily and robustly incorporate their products into high-performance buildings. It also will be used internally by manufacturers for R&D purposes to evaluate and position their own products for sales and marketing, as well as for developing their next generation technologies. The specifier community of architects, consultants, and engineers will also benefit from these models since they can verify if their buildings will perform as designed. Building occupants will benefit from improved access to usable daylight and will have less reliance on electrical lighting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Light Foundry LLC’s completion of the NSF SBIR-I project resulted in an initial GlareProbe prototype (MVP).  

GlareProbe is a semi-autonomous software program built on top of Light Foundry’s current daylighting software, LightStanza.  GlareProbe takes the hardest part of analyzing light into a building and distills it into highly functional solutions for a specific project.  Light Foundry’s unique and advanced interdisciplinary approach of HPC, UX and lighting science spans NSF’s areas of research in Advanced Manufacturing and Nanotechnology, Information Technologies, Internet of Things, and Educational Technologies and Applications.  

As buildings currently account for an estimated one-third of global emissions, green buildings are one of the most cost-effective solutions to climate change because they generate significant environmental, economic and societal benefits.  Most people are in buildings during the day - on average, Americans spend approximately 90% of their time indoors.  It is widely accepted that a critical component to green building design is the employment of appropriate daylighting and electrical lighting strategies. Fundamental to any lighting strategy is the mitigation of glare; as glare is the the number one cause for daylight strategies being defeated. Glare is a complex multidimensional phenomena, varying by location, time of day, weather, and orientation.

The vast majority of green buildings are designed by teams of professionals who are non-experts.  GlareProbe provides architects and consultants with a networked-based, fast and accurate tool that allows them to visualize, understand, and compare day/lighting design solutions with respect to their impact on other systems and occupant comfort, to help make informed, meaningful decisions backed by accurate, actionable, conclusive data and metrics.  The tool provides manufacturers of advanced daylighting products a flexible, parametric and accessible tool to optimize the operations of their products, and show product performance to specifiers.  The tool allows for the education of the masses on highly technical and esoteric daylighting metrics through accessible images, animations and easy-to-use  green-building scorecards.  GlareProbe improves buildings by translating the value of design decisions with regard to day/lighting, in terms of cost, aesthetics, lighting energy use, human health and well-being.  

GlareProbe utilizes innovative techniques to efficiently compute glare.  Through the development of novel geometric algorithms, it successfully automates the 3-phase fast lighting calculation method for commercial use.  GlareProbe also developed an initial innovative architecture, breaking massive amounts of lighting simulation analysis into a tree-like structure for optimal parallel computation.  It was tested on several complex spaces encompassing commercial and educational buildings.  Through hands on user-studies, several domain experts validated and developed this concept.  The underlying technology that makes the annual glare analysis possible is highly innovative. The annual analysis finds and calculates the most problematic glare hot-spots throughout an entire 3D model, at hundreds of locations and orientations for all daylight hours of a year, then compiles the results to deliver the user an effective glare report focusing on priority areas of concern. Performing this type of analysis using traditional methods is unfeasible as it would take months of computation time, nor does there exist effective ways of communicating results to users. GlareProbe delivers this analysis on the order of minutes.

As a result of the NSF SBIR-I project, Light Foundry provided educational presentations on daylighting analysis and simulation at various international green-building conferences, including US Green Building Council’s Rocky Mountain Green and Rocky Mountain Lights.  American Institute of Architects DC and Omaha, the International Building Performance Simulation Association NYC, the Pacific Energy Center San Francisco, and the Berkeley Building Science Group.  The lectures discussed the strengths and weaknesses of current glare measurement strategies, and increased awareness and understanding of needed glare simulation technologies.

The widespread use of GlareProbe by green building professionals will undoubtedly lead to achieving goals set out in global sustainability initiatives such as LEED ( Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design), the WELL Building Standard, Architecture 2030, Net Zero Energy Building, the IECC (International Energy Conservation Code), among many other codes focused on high performance building and carbon neutrality.  These industry standards make human factors a priority through daylight design.  

World-wide green building is expected to double every three years.  The world’s green building market is a trillion-dollar industry, and the green building materials market is expected to reach $234 billion by 2019.  By 2018, green construction will directly contribute 1.1 million jobs and $75.6 billion in wages by 2018 in the United States.  Between 2015 and 2018, LEED-certified buildings in the United States are estimated to have $1.2 billion in energy savings.  Green buildings use fewer energy and water resources; save money for families, businesses and taxpayers; reduce carbon emissions; and prioritize environmental and human health.  To this end, GlareProbe is the only web-based software that can accurately calculate Spatial Daylight Autonomy (sDA) with dynamic blinds operation, required for LEED compliance, and the only program that can provide whole-building glare analysis.
